This game literally changed my life. Ever since this game came out, all I can do is play Overwatch 2 from the moment I wake up to the moment I fall asleep.

Originally, I purchased this game to play with my friends, but after forcing them to play about five games in a row, they all decided they’d had enough for the day. My intense desire for Overwatch 2 wasn’t satisfied, so I moved on to playing against a full room of AI. After my tenth game against five hard AI, I was still not satisfied, but my urge had to wait as I passed out before I could start a new game.

When I woke up, I plugged it in and went straight back to playing Overwatch 2. I played one round with five hard AI, but my urge simply got worse. I figured I wasn’t getting my fill since it took too long between my turns. I decided to change it to one hard AI, but after about three games I started to get impatient — to the point that I was screaming at the top of my lungs, telling the AI to hurry up so I could play.

It was around this time that my mother came into my room, telling me I had woken her up and that she was taking my PC away so she could get some sleep. Rage filled my body and, without even thinking, I punched her directly in the face and started screaming again as her body dropped to the ground.

I took her body, tied it to the bed, and gagged her so that when she woke up she wouldn’t be able to open her stupid mouth and tell me to stop playing the most amazing game known as Overwatch 2 for the PC.

When I finally got back to my game, my urge was so intense that I decided to start up a local multiplayer game with two players so I would always be playing. After about five games with myself, I started to calm down and realized that life would be okay — because I had Overwatch 2, and I never had to stop playing.

In the middle of the sixth game, my mom woke up and I started to hear her muffled screams. I told her she’d better shut up or I’d never let her go. After that, she quieted down — but little did she know, I would never let her go. I couldn’t risk letting her, or anyone for that matter, stop me from playing my game.

It’s now been ten days and I haven’t stopped playing since that morning. I’ve lost track of how many games I’ve played. I haven’t left my house, and my friends seem to be worried about me because they’ve called my phone multiple times in the past hour. But I don’t have time to talk to people who don’t love Overwatch 2 the way I do.

My mother stopped moving two days ago and is starting to smell — but I don’t care, because I have everything I need: Overwatch 2.

Titlu: Eroi, Haos și Nerf-uri Infinite – Overwatch 2

★★★★☆ Recomand (dar cu capul pe umeri)

Overwatch 2 este încercarea Blizzard de a reinventa cel mai popular hero-shooter al deceniului. Rezultatul? Un joc energic, frumos, rapid, dar și un pic controversat. Dacă-l privești strict ca shooter competitiv pe echipe, e clar că încă are magia aia care te prinde. Dacă-l privești ca pe promisiunea „Overwatch 2” inițială… ei bine, acolo e altă discuție.

Atmosferă & Prezentare

Overwatch 2 rămâne unul dintre cele mai colorate și stilizate shootere existente. Eroii sunt carismatici, animațiile impecabile, efectele spectaculoase, iar designul hărților arată ca un mix de artă futuristă și detalii care fac lumea să pară vie.
E un joc care se simte “pozitiv”, luminos și vibrant, chiar dacă în interior e un haos total.

Gameplay

Aici strălucește.
Trecerea la formatul 5v5 face luptele mai rapide și mai personale. Fiecare erou chiar contează, iar rolurile sunt clare: tank, damage, suport. Abilitățile sunt unice, mecanicile sunt fluide, iar fiecare meci e o explozie de adrenalină.

Coordonarea echipei poate transforma o partidă într-o operă de artă. Lipsa coordonării… într-un coșmar care te face să închizi jocul pentru „5 minute” (care devin 2 ore).

Puncte Tari

Gameplay extrem de fluid, distractiv și bine calibrat.

E gratuit — intri rapid, fără investiții.

Eroi diverși, fiecare cu vibe și mecanici unice.

Stil vizual fenomenal și animații de top.

Ritm alert, lupte spectaculoase și meciuri intense.

Puncte Slabe

Promisiunile legate de modurile PvE și campanie… au dispărut în fum.

Monetizare agresivă — skin-urile sunt frumoase, dar scumpe rău.

Balansul eroilor sare uneori dintr-o extremă în alta.

Experiența depinde TOTAL de echipă; fără coordonare, te enervezi instant.

Comunitatea poate fi… intensă, ca să zicem frumos.

Concluzie

Overwatch 2 nu e revoluția promisă, dar este un shooter excelent atunci când totul se aliniază. Are un „fun factor” uriaș, un stil vizual superb și un gameplay rafinat ani la rând. E o experiență ideală pentru cei care iubesc luptele pe echipe, eroii cu abilități speciale și adrenalina la fiecare colț.

Honest long review by me.

I’ve been playing Overwatch since December 2016. Back then, the game actually meant something. Matches took skill, teamwork, and timing. Pulling off a clutch felt earned. Heroes had identity, fights had weight, and every win was yours. Fast forward to 2025 and I barely recognize what I’m playing. The soul is gone. It’s a hollow, frustrating shell of what once was one of the best games ever made.

Matchmaking has been trash for YEARS. I don’t know if it’s EOMM, SBMM, hidden throttling, or just pure incompetence, but matches feel predetermined. One game you stomp, the next you get thrown into a blender. It never feels like you win because you played well — it feels like the system decided the outcome the moment you queued. It’s exhausting, and it’s been this way since I first touched the game.

Season 9 was the point where Blizzard completely killed skill expression. Every patch since then is built around flattening the game and making precision irrelevant. Tanks are raid bosses, supports are basically DPS with insane sustain, and DPS is just… cosmetic. You can land every shot and it still doesn’t matter because the sustain loop is busted. They call it “accessibility,” but it’s really the death of competitive integrity. Years of learning mechanics, tracking, positioning — all of that means nothing now.

The devs keep insisting 5v5 is “better,” but all it did was destroy the role ecosystem. Tanks feel awful unless they’re overtuned, supports only shine by turning into mini-tanks, and DPS is irrelevant unless something is accidentally broken. Every balance patch feels like it was designed by developers who’ve never played above Bronze. Instead of fixing meaningful issues, they buff easy heroes, nerf depth, and pretend they’re saving the game.

Then we have the company behind all this. Blizzard isn’t Blizzard anymore. The harassment scandals, the studio culture issues, the PR nonsense — everything behind the scenes mirrors the state of the game. Hollow, directionless, and full of ego. They talk about “trusting the vision,” but the vision is a dumpster fire.

And the hero identity? Completely gone. They’ve abandoned edgy, skill-heavy heroes like Hanzo, Sombra, and Reaper. Permanent underdogs now. In their place, we get shiny, safe, streamer-friendly characters. And speaking of new characters — Vendetta is literally a knock-off Magik from Marvel Rivals. Same look, same vibe, same glowing magic-sword aesthetic. It’s embarrassing. They really thought their copy could compete with the actual Queen of Limbo? Be serious.

To make it even funnier, Blizzard emailed me saying I “qualified for a free Premium Battle Pass due to login issues.” I never had any. They’re just handing out passes like apology coupons now. What a joke.

The community is another disaster. Somehow people think Overwatch 2 is at its “peak.” They cheer for pointless modes like Stadium — something nobody asked for — while the actual competitive experience is falling apart. It’s Fortnite with ultimates now. Casual hype drowns out any real feedback, and anyone who points out the game’s decline gets treated like the problem.

I’ve actually had to force myself to play other games just to feel skill matter again. Need for Speed — a racing game — gives me more satisfaction because your mistakes are yours. Meanwhile, Overwatch feels rigged or random. Wins and losses feel like matchmaking dice rolls, not performance.

Custom games used to be a place to escape the chaos. Now they’re ruined too. Fake-friendly lobbies full of creeps, drama, harassment, and weirdos. Blizzard does absolutely nothing. They never have. Moderation is cosmetic — just like half the game mechanics now.

Then there’s the monetization. Every new season is “BUY MORE KIRIKO SKINS,” “Check out the new bundle,” “Look at the new crossover event.” Everything feels like a commercial. Even hero buffs feel like marketing pushes. The game’s direction is driven by engagement metrics, not gameplay health. They don’t balance for fun or fairness — they balance for attention spans.

It’s been a slow, painful decline. I kept hoping the game would recover, that Blizzard would fix matchmaking, revive skill-based play, bring back hero identity. But every patch proves they’re going the opposite direction. The game gets more chaotic, more casual-focused, more empty.

Overwatch now feels like watching a corpse move. The animations are pretty, the maps are nice, the heroes look cool — but the soul is missing. There’s no tension, no clutch value, no sense that your input matters. Winning rarely feels earned. Losing feels predetermined. Everything that made it special has been replaced by noise, spam, sustain, and monetization.

The casual community celebrates meaningless skins and overhyped updates while ignoring the actual problems. They cheer for fluff while the core rots. It’s painful to watch a game you loved slowly sink while people clap at the fireworks on the deck.

I’ve held on for too long. I kept telling myself it could get better. But it hasn’t. Every patch reminds me:
the devs don’t care about skill, don’t care about veterans, and don’t care about the identity this game once had.

Overwatch used to be a masterpiece.
Now it’s a flashy, hollow shell propped up by marketing, casual hype, and nostalgia.

I wish it wasn’t this way.

This essay explores the many reasons why Overwatch 2 is a horrible game and why gamers should think twice before investing their time, money, and hope in it.

1. The Illusion of Innovation
When Blizzard announced Overwatch 2, fans expected a meaningful sequel with significant improvements and new content. Instead, what they received was an incremental update masquerading as a new game. The much-touted shift from 6v6 to 5v5 gameplay did little to fundamentally alter the core experience. Maps, heroes, and game modes were slightly tweaked, but the changes felt superficial at best. Many players noted that Overwatch 2 played almost identically to the original, with only a handful of new heroes and maps that could have easily been introduced as updates to the first game.

Perhaps the most egregious example of this lack of innovation is the handling of the promised PvE (Player vs. Environment) mode. This feature was heavily marketed as the cornerstone of Overwatch 2, setting it apart from its predecessor and justifying its existence as a sequel. However, Blizzard eventually scrapped the ambitious PvE campaign, leaving players with a glorified patch rather than a true sequel. This broken promise eroded trust and demonstrated a fundamental disregard for the community’s expectations.

2. Monetization and Corporate Greed
If there is one aspect where Overwatch 2 stands out, it is in its aggressive monetization strategies. The original Overwatch adopted a “buy once, play forever” model, with cosmetic items available through loot boxes that could be earned through gameplay. While loot boxes are controversial, they at least allowed dedicated players to unlock content without spending additional money.

Overwatch 2, on the other hand, is free-to-play—but at a significant cost. The introduction of battle passes, expensive cosmetics, and paywalls for new heroes has transformed the game into a cash grab. Players now have to pay real money or grind for dozens of hours to access new content, and the prices for skins and bundles are exorbitant. This shift in philosophy prioritizes profits over player enjoyment, creating an environment where those who pay are often rewarded more than those who play.

Moreover, the decision to lock new heroes behind the battle pass undermines the competitive integrity of the game. In a title where team composition and hero selection are crucial, forcing players to unlock heroes through progression or payment creates an uneven playing field. This pay-to-win perception has alienated both new and returning players, further damaging the game’s reputation.

3. Disregard for the Community
A successful multiplayer game thrives on its community, but Blizzard’s handling of Overwatch 2 demonstrates a striking lack of respect for its player base. Communication has been inconsistent, with frequent delays and vague updates about the game’s direction. The scrapping of the PvE mode, as previously mentioned, was not only a broken promise but also a blatant disregard for the excitement and anticipation of long-time fans.

Additionally, the forced migration from Overwatch to Overwatch 2, which included the shutdown of the original game’s servers, left many players feeling betrayed. Those who preferred the original’s mechanics, balance, or business model were given no choice but to adapt or quit. This move eliminated player agency and erased years of gaming history, all for the sake of pushing a lackluster sequel.

Toxicity and cheating have also become more prevalent in Overwatch 2. Despite promises of better moderation and anti-cheat systems, many players report that these issues are worse than ever. The lack of meaningful community tools, such as robust reporting and matchmaking improvements, has only exacerbated these problems.

4. Gameplay and Balance Issues
On a fundamental level, Overwatch 2 suffers from numerous gameplay and balance issues. The shift to 5v5 has not been universally well-received. Many players feel that the loss of a second tank has made matches more chaotic, less strategic, and more punishing for solo players. The meta is often dominated by a handful of overpowered heroes, while others languish in obscurity due to poor balancing.

Frequent balance patches and hero reworks have not resolved these problems; in some cases, they have made things worse by introducing new bugs or unintended consequences. The game now feels less like a carefully crafted competitive experience and more like an experimental testbed, where players are subjected to constant changes and disruptions. This instability is frustrating for both casual and competitive players, who crave consistency and fairness.

5. Technical and Quality-of-Life Failures
Beyond its design flaws, Overwatch 2 is plagued by technical issues and a lack of quality-of-life improvements. Server problems, long queue times, and frequent disconnections are common complaints. Despite being marketed as a next-generation upgrade, the game still suffers from outdated graphics, clunky user interfaces, and limited accessibility options.

Basic features that are standard in other competitive games—such as robust stat tracking, replay systems, and customizable controls—are either missing or poorly implemented. These oversights further contribute to the sense that Overwatch 2 is a rushed and incomplete product.

6. The Decline of Blizzard’s Reputation
Blizzard was once a name synonymous with quality and innovation. The company’s decline has been well-documented, from controversies over workplace culture to questionable business decisions. Overwatch 2 represents the culmination of this downward spiral—a game designed more by committee and corporate mandate than by passion and creativity.

By supporting Overwatch 2, players are not only endorsing a mediocre game but also enabling the practices that have led to Blizzard’s fall from grace. There are countless other games, both old and new, that deserve your time and money more than this disappointing sequel.

Conclusion: Choose Better
In summary, Overwatch 2 is a deeply flawed game that fails to justify its existence as a sequel. It offers little innovation, prioritizes monetization over enjoyment, disrespects its community, and suffers from numerous gameplay and technical issues. The forced migration from Overwatch to its inferior successor is a stark reminder of how far Blizzard has strayed from its roots.

If you value your time, your money, and your love for gaming, do not play Overwatch 2. There are far better alternatives that respect their players, foster positive communities, and deliver genuinely innovative experiences. Let Overwatch 2 serve as a warning: demand more from the games you play, and never settle for less.
